n some cases, it may be necessary to use multiple access points within a small area. To avoid interference between access points, it is important to use non-overlapping channels. comments.content:
You'd better to choose WPA.
Check bottom of page#14 on https://www.grc.com/sn/sn-170.pdf. 
 WPA only had to have TKIP. WPA2 has both. And so it's not the case, for example, that WPA2 no longer has TKIP. It has both. It's got the final version of the AES approach.
And as per last requirement, "The Access Points should be configured to only support TKIP clients at a maximum speed", WPA is the one that only support TKIP whereas WPA supports TKIP and AES (CCMP).

Did you mean WPA2 supports TKIP and AES? You had to...
https://www.comparitech.com/blog/information-security/wpa2-aes-tkip/#:~:text=WPA2%2DPersonal%20%E2%80%93%20Supports%20CCMP%20(,Extensible%20Authentication%20Protocol%20(EAP).

questions.question_text: A network administrator is configuring a load balancer for two systems. Which of the following must the administrator configure to ensure connectivity during a failover?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
- Virtual IP (VIP): A virtual IP address should be configured on the load balancer, which is the IP address that clients use to access the load-balanced systems.

Selected Answer: A
You can use a virtual IP to achieve load balancing across multiple interfaces.

Selected Answer: A
Virtual IP Address (VIP or VIPA) = An IP address that does not correlate to an actual physical network interface used for NAT, fault-tolerance & virtualization. In your computer you have a NIC, normally you can only configure the NIC with a single IP address due to one physical network interface (the NIC). A VIPA will let you configure that NIC to respond to numerous IP addresses & all resolve back to physical network interface to establish network activity. Routers will often use VIPAs to provide redundancy in connectivity options by having a single VIPA assigned to the default gateway, this will allow multiple routers that can answer on behalf of the VIPA, allowing a primary device to use during normal conditions & alternate devices that can be used when primary device fails.

Selected Answer: A
P Public address of a load 
balanced cluster that is shared by the 
devices implementing the cluster.
I honestly don't understand the question

Selected Answer: A
Virtual IP is the correct one

comments.content: the other answers make less sense. But VIP is configured on load balanced router pairs.

discussion.content: I do not see why it has to be a Virtual IP ...

Selected Answer: A
a vip is correct

Selected Answer: A
Virtual IP

Selected Answer: D
If users on each floor have stable connectivity within their own floor but are having trouble connecting to other floors, it suggests that the problem lies in the device that interconnects the networks of all floors, which is typically the core switch.

Selected Answer: D
Edge switches in IDF support each floor and they are working fine

Selected Answer: D
Core Switch
The core switch is the backbone of your network. It's the most important piece of equipment because it connects all your other switches and routes traffic between them. The access switch, on the other hand, connects end users like computers or printers to the network via Ethernet cables.
https://www.ruijienetworks.com/support/tech-gallery/core-switches-and-access-switches#:~:text=The%20core%20switch%20is%20the,the%20network%20via%20Ethernet%20cables.

Selected Answer: D
D. Core switch

The described issue, where users on each floor have stable connectivity but face problems when trying to connect to other floors, suggests a potential problem with inter-floor communication. In a large building with multiple floors, a core switch is responsible for routing traffic between different subnets or VLANs. If there are issues with connectivity between floors, the core switch would be the primary suspect.

Selected Answer: B
Given the description of the issue, where users on each floor have stable connectivity but not with other floors, the likely culprit is a device responsible for connecting different floors. In this scenario, the most likely cause of the issue is:

B. Edge devices

Edge devices typically handle the connectivity between different networks or segments, and if users on each floor have stable connectivity within their floor but not across floors, it suggests a problem with the devices at the edges of each floor's network. Edge devices could include routers or layer 3 switches responsible for inter-floor communication.

questions.question_text: A technician received a report that some users in a large, 30-floor building are having intermittent connectivity issues. Users on each floor have stable connectivity, but do not have connectivity to other floors. Which of the following devices is MOST likely causing the issue?

choices.C: The technician was testing a theory to determine the cause.
choices.A: The technician was approaching multiple problems individually.
choices.D: The technician was identifying the problem by gathering information.
choices.B: The technician was establishing a plan of action and identifying potential effects.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
He already confirmed the problem.

comments.content: Agreed. Correct answer is B
Absolutely wrong…the notes from the previous technician stated he found a problem…the new technician found the old notes…new technician is found D which is gathering and identifying…
Definitely not C, he’s reviewing or gathering information…he’s not in the step C…answer is D

discussion.content: Good Day. I was getting confused with this question and the community's answer. The answer is C. I read the statement several times and reviewed the 6 steps to troubleshooting. The technician never stated the cause of the issue. The technician simply confirmed that there was an issue and that the system version will be updated. Then the technician will monitor the issue as instructed by the developer to determine the actual "cause". If the technician already knew the cause, the statement would have read differently. The technician would have noted that updating the system (plan of action) resolved the issue. In the purest sense of step 4 "Establish/Creat A Plan of Action, there was no discussion noted about potential effects either. Just my thoughts. Imma go with C for the test.

Selected Answer: D
Absolutely wrong…the notes from the previous technician stated he found a problem…the new technician found the old notes…new technician is doing D which is gathering and identifying…hint here is there’s two technicians one who wrote the notes and one currently working on the ticket…question is asking about the current technician…

Selected Answer: C
Answer is B.

He's still "monitoring for connectivity problems" after applying the update, meaning that updating the system is just a *theoretical* solution, not the *absolute* solution.

If their results confirm it, then establishing a plan would be upgrading **all other systems that need it**.

comments.content: Excuse me, C*. The answer is C.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
the correct answer is B.

Selected Answer: C
The technician confirmed there is a problem & established the theory that the system was out of date. The technician is now testing the theory by updating the customer's system & monitoring it for failure.

Selected Answer: B
Problem has been already confirmed.

Selected Answer: B
B. The technician was establishing a plan of action and identifying potential effects.

The note indicates that the technician has confirmed the customer's problem with the system and has a plan of action to address it. The plan involves upgrading the system to the latest version and monitoring for further connectivity problems based on the instructions from the developer. This aligns with the idea of establishing a plan of action and considering potential effects that may arise from the upgrade. Therefore, the most fitting option is B.

Selected Answer: B
should be B. The technician was establishing a plan of action and identifying potential effects.

questions.question_text:
A help desk technician discovers the following note while reviewing tickets in a customer's account:

Was able to confirm customer's problem with the system. Will upgrade system to latest version and monitor for further connectivity problems per developer's instructions.

Which of the following describes what the technician was documenting with this note?

choices.B: Implement directional antennas on AP1 and AP2.
choices.D: Change the SSID on AP1 and AP2.
choices.A: Reconfigure AP2 and AP3 for non-overlapping channels.
choices.C: Raise the power settings on AP2 and AP3.

discussion.content: I don't get some of these questions. Without knowing the exact placement of each access point, how can we determine from this chart that the antennas need to be replaced.

comments.content:
Normally I would agree with you since CompTIA's known for it's very confusing wording, but in this case it's actually very simple:

Undesired RSSI means the wifi signals are making it beyond where you want it to be. With just that info, you can eliminate C since raising the power level would only make it worse. Reconfiguring AP2 and AP3 to have non-overlapping channels would actually HELP this network, but we're trying to limit the network not improve it, so that eliminates A. And changing the SSID would have no impact on the wireless signals making it out of the building or not, so that eliminates D.

The only possible answer that meets the requirements is B. Omni-directional means it radiates outward in all directions so surely that's the source of the problem. Even if those APs were in the middle of the building and not making it outside, the other answers make 0 impact on primary problem.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
best option listed to prevent access in the outside areas is to use directional antennas.

It's C. Raise the power settings on AP2 and AP3.
AP1 has strong signal so all devices are connecting to it

I guess that changing the antennas to directional would fix the issue with unwanted exterior access. The Omnidirectional antennas could be covering an area larger than needed. I think they threw the overlapping channel in there to confuse us maybe? Let me know if i am mistaken
